While visiting SF went here for dinner and it was pretty good! The ambiance is somewhat casual and the waitresses are all dressed up in Traditional Thai dresses, very ornate and colorful!

They bring you rice in a ornate metal pot and the food comes out very stylishly plated.

We ordered the yellow curry, the green curry, pad thai, Tom Ka Ga soup and pineapple rice. They were all very good. Not too spicey, and not too salty like some places butcher Thai food.

I would say the most authentic I've had, and I have a friend who is Thai, so I have had authentic thai home cooking previously!

If you're ever in the area, I recommend going!
author: Pearl H.

description:
This is another restaurant that I walked by something like 17,305 times before finally trying it...and damn, was it good!

I went here with a group of friends and we started with the angel wings (deep fried chicken wings) and the Tom Yum soup, both of which were excellent. For our main courses we had chicken in basil and garlic, chicken with spinach in peanut sauce, shrimp Pad Thai and chicken fried rice (what's up with all the chicken?), and of these four dishes the only one that was so-so was the fried rice...and that's because I prefer steamed rice with my Thai food.

The service was top-notch and the decor was nice and comfy...the only negative to the whole experience was that the table we sat at was smallish for four people (good thing we didn't get the green papaya salad I wanted, but next time...next time), and could barely handle the volume of food we ate.

I enjoyed a great Thai iced tea with our feast, and rolled out of there quite fat and happy. I'll definitely make it back here, especially since this location is in one of my current favorite 'hoods in the city!
author: Art D.

description:
I'm in food a rut at Marnee Thai.  I've found some menu items that I just love, and I can't seem to branch out to find others because I'm enamored with my favorites.  I'm trapped in the tunnel vision of limited Thai deliciousness, and I can't escape.

- - - - - - - - -
Here are some delectable rut-makers...

Pad Thai: A standard at any Thai restaurant, but not one I generally eat because I find it sometimes has a tendency to taste a bit like stale dog food, if not made properly.  Not the case at Marnee Thai.  Fabulous and tangy on a consistent basis.

Pad Se-Ew:  It's confusing because it ends in "ew", but that doesn't mean I don't like it.  The "ew" is them, not me.

Spicy Angel Wings: Easy to spell and easy to eat.  I've not had the chicken version, but the deep fried tofu triangle version is fantastic.
- - - - - - - - -

I would give five stars, but some of their sauces are inconsistent, especially the Pad Se-Ew.  So, four stars with a little room for improvement.

If you don't have time to eat-in, they won't deliver, but they cheerfully do take out, so call on your way home from work and swing by.  It's worth it.  Also close to the N-Judah and easily bike-able.

Bonus: Some of their best recipes are listed on their website!
author: Bert M.

description:
EDIT 09/29/07:  It's been practically two years since I've eaten here last, and the food is just as good as I remember it being.  Portions are just right and the flavor is on point.  Perhaps I'm being stingy at a 4...I can't pinpoint it, but something prevents me from giving a 5.  (Maybe it was the loud banging of the pots and pans during our meal?)  

---------

Marnee features decent Thai food--nothing really standout.  But I do appreciate that their menu lists more than the standard vegetarian dishes by offering a faux meat substitute of soy protein with your choice of seasoning.   

Other than the tables being in close proximity to one another, I don't remember much about this location. The small, candlelit table might prompt you to reach out and hold hands with the person sitting across from you, even if you're just having dinner with an old friend. It was eerily romantic.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Just1 and I were randomly criss-crossing SF after having spent a rainy afternoon at the DeYoung...  I remembered there being a bar called the Mucky Duck that I wanted to go have a bloody mary at.

I knew another friend of mine lived somewhere way the hell out here, so I called him up to inquire where the bar was.  We go there and had a drink and I asked about the yumminess factor of this other Thai joint down the street.  I was told that Marnee Thai was the shizzle.  Just1 had NEVER had Thai before!  WTF?!

So of course we have to go get out of the rain and have some Thai food.

All of my favorites were perfect (chicken satay, corn fritters and tom yum gai soup) and I had a dish with chicken and cashews that was AWESOME.  Just1 ordered chicken curry (that I didn't end up trying) and Pickles (Jason's new nick name starting that evening) had beef with green beans.

All the food was super fresh and quite tasty.  The service was attentive.  I'd definitely go back and will the next time I'm all the way out THERE!
author: MoMo D.

description:
My Grandmother came into town to visit. When she told me she wanted me to pick the place for dinner I was dumb struck. She has been all over the world and been to some of the best restaurants in the world (including SF).

Luckily she narrowed it down by saying she wanted something Asian. After some brief research I decided on Marnee Thai and prayed it worked out.

To make a long story short she loved everything we got ( 5 dishes because "it all looked so good" and she HAD to try it all)

The location was comfy and the staff was very helpful and accommodating. Thanks Marnee Thai you saved my tush!!

You truly can't go wrong there!
author: rachel c.

description:
Marnee Thai is my favorite Thai place in the city.  A lot of people are hating on the location, but as an avid Le Video customer, it could not be more convenient for a night of take out and cult movies.

Things to try: Pad See Lew, Roasted Duck (Holy crap is this good), the BBQ  Chicken and Pad Pra Ram (seriously you may end up licking the sauce off the plate invoking well worth it stares).

This is making me hungry.
author: Erica O.

description:
Funny how I used to think SF was short on Thai food; now that I've been to the 4 corners of the Sunset Thai scene (Chabaa, Vanida, Silver Spoon, and here), it seems downright bounteous.  So which is the best?  Depends on the dish, really.   Silver Spoon's Evil Jungle Prince is one hell of a signature dish...but Marnee's Pad Kee Mow is the best I've ever had.   And they have pumpkin samosas--nice.  Clearly, only time will tell.

One nice thing about Marnee is their hidden back room which makes the restaurant much larger than its cramped, bustling front area would suggest; it's pretty rare that a party of 7 can just stroll in and get seated right away on a weekend, even (especially?) in the Inner Sunset.  A few of the dishes got brought out late, but they're diligent about keeping the hot tea coming.  

Note: this Marnee is a spin-off of the original in the Outer Sunset, but being closer to home, it's my location of choice.
author: Wes M.

description:
If I get to the pearly gates and the Angel Gabrielle asks if I would like to enter the gates of heaven I will ask for the Marnee Thai Angel Wings please and Gabrielle will know what I am talking about since he can see everything from up there and he will be like "fuck yeah" and I will be like "fuck yeah" and we'll high five and when our hands slapp together sparks will shoot off like lightening bolts and Marilyn Monroe will be watching from inside the gates and she will be all like "that guy is hot".

I've never been to Thailand but I have been to DeliciousTown.

I can honestly say I have not had better Thai anywhere - and I have been to Thai dumps and Thai fine dining and none of them are as solidly good as this - and all for a great price!

The staff is pleasant and the decor is charming with a cozy feel.
author: scott w.

description: This is the other location of this Thai restaurant.  Like the other one on 21st and Irving, the food and service is great.  Angel wings are always a staple and any of the curry dishes are yummy.  Although I prefer the other location, this one is much smaller and feels tighter but it is centrally located in a hipster neighborhood and close to Golden Gate park.  Parking is ridiculous but public transportation is so convenient.  Always an awesome place to eat and even better that you can walk off the calories through the hood or at the park!
author: Elle H.

description:
So I've been to Thailand but never became a food critic.  I was suggested to try Marnee Thai and this weekend on my way to walking around GG Park I decided to try it out.

I ordered the Red Chicken Curry and it was good.  The atmosphere was nice and the lady who sat me pretty much told me what to do the whole time so it made it kind of odd but easy.  

I'll definitely be back and try other dishes.
author: Matthew G.

description: Don't ever ask for "extra spicy" or the chef will make your food completely inedible! Don't believe me? Try it for yourself and feel your esophagus bleed!
author: Suany W.

description: A nice place for some Thai food, you definitely can't go wrong with their Basil Chicken, Pad Thai and Coconut Soup. Great service too, the waiters are a lot friendlier than other Thai places in the Bay Area.  If you want delicious Thai food with good service check it out. Also a pretty convenient location, Teaway is right across the street so you can get your thai iced tea with boba for desert, nice bonus : ).
author: Leighton M.

description:
I think I know what's going on. People walk into Thep Phanom with massively inflated expectations. They discover it's good, not exceptional, and give it 3 stars. People walk into Marnee, it's like their little discovery in the Sunset. 5 stars. Well dammit pretty soon Marnee will be the overhyped one. 

Anyway, both are very good and have their on and off days. It's a very close contest. Really close. I mean, it's just impossible to declare a clear victor. In fact, you could call it a............. trying to think of the right word here......... um............ A draw? No, that doesn't sound quite right. Damn what am I trying to say here.... a dead heat? Nah that's no good either. How about a... stalemate? A match? A toss-up?? A photo finish???? Nope, those just don't cut it.

Oh well, I guess I'll try to think of a better word some other time.
author: Tom L.

description:
Marnee Thai is possibly the tastiest Thai place in the city. 

The Place: interior is traditional, bamboo and feels like you're in a hut in Thailand eating home cooking. Lots of bejeweled elephants

The Food: Awesome. Tastes different than the 3000 other Thai spots I've been to in the city. Get the Spicy Chicken Wings, Chicken and Garlic, Beef Green Curry w/Eggplant, Pad Thai, BBQ Pork. Mango Sticky rice for dessert was good too. Go with a lot of people and share like 10 dishes family style. It's so cheap, it came out to $20/person for 13 of us

The People: Mama Thai is loud and fun. She's friendly and knows exactly what you should get and makes good reco's. They wear traditional Thai dress and provide great service
author: Peter K.

description:
On a cold, misty November day, there's nothing better than a bowl of Tom Ka soup from Marnee Thai.... coconut, lemongrass, ginger, and just a hint of spiciness.  It's perfection!  And when I have a head cold, it's WAY better than chicken noodle soup.  

They also make a really good pad thai, and they have this delicious crab & mango salad that's delightful.

The servers are always friendly and attentive.  They always keep my water glass filled, and I never had to wait too long for the check.  

Even though the place is pretty small, I've never had to wait for a table at lunchtime (although I tend to go to lunch around 1:00, which probably makes a difference).
author: Jane A.

description:
I consider myself a Thai food enthusiast, and have been searching for a quality Thai restaurant in San Francisco that could meet my expectations set by the extremely authentic Thai restaurant I use to go to before moving here two years ago. After trying many sub-par and embarrassingly horrible Thai places like King of Thai I had all but given up hope on finding good Thai food in San Francisco. Despite skepticism, I decided to take my best friend (who is also a Thai enthusiast) out for her birthday with a group of our closest girlfriends.

To start let me just commend Marnee Thai for being extremely patient during the reservation process. I called the day before the dinner was to take place (which I felt bad for on such short notice for a Friday night). Marnee was more than happy to accommodate me and my party of 8 during peak hours on a Friday night. *If you have ever tried to get any number of  "20-something" girls together, on time, to go to anywhere on a Friday night you will feel my pain.* So, of course many of my friends were not ready to leave at the time of our reservation. I called and apologized to the staff and told them we would be late. They asked if I would like for them to hold our table, but having worked in the restaurant business myself, knowing it was peak hours on a Friday night, and my eight friends would probably not be ready for another full hour (a long enough time for Marnee to turn a table), I declined. When we arrived (a full hour after our reservation time) they were still polite to us and sat us within 5 minutes. They also get kudos for seating us in an intimate spot in the back, which was perfect for celebrating my best friends birthday with my rambunctious friends. 

We order quite a bit of food, and Marnee was able to accommodate a friend in our party who had a peanut allergy (which is rare among Thai restaurants where peanuts are an integral part of cooking).  The food was extremely good. I would highly recommend the Beef Salad and the Avocado Salad (which was a special the night we went). Their Pad Thai was good, though comparable to the Pad Thai I got at my old Thai place. However, for me, the true test is always the Tom Kha Gai (the chicken coconut soup). Growing up in what I fondly refer to as "eclectic family" with a mother who doesn't cook much, instead of getting chicken soup when I was sick growing up my mom would run out and get me Tom Kha Gai. I was thoroughly impressed by their interpretation of Tom Kha Gai and will definitely go back for more of my childhood comfort food.We also ordered some beer and sake but surprisingly our bill was small for a party of 8. 

Those on here who complain about Marnee Thai's cost obviously are not accustomed to eating out in San Francisco. I am a college student, thus extremely poor, but taking my best friend out for her birthday did not break the bank.  What you pay for is definitely worth the quality. I had an amazing time celebrating my best friends birthday and was relieved to have finally found a quality Thai restaurant in the city that I can go to and take my family to when they are here visiting. I would highly recommend Marnee Thai to anyone searching for good Thai in San Francisco.
author: Sarah S.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! I've been going here for over 20 years. I have tried so many other Thai restaurants, but this one is the best. Even though I no longer live 3 blocks away, I'll go across town just to eat there. YUMMY!!!
author: Mary M.

description:
Sunday early evening and my friends send me on an almost pointless drive around the Sunset.  Tells me to drive to Xbar for shabu shabu but it's closed for business, then Noriega for Korean, only to change their mind, then sushi at Ebisu and they don't open on Sunday....WTH???  So by total chance we walk into Marnee which is a few doors down.  From the outside I wasn't trilled that we were eating here.  Looked like a cheesy Asian take out place, but to my surprise the dining area inside was actually nice.  Servers are dressed in Thai garb.

We ordered:

Mango Salad - mangos sweet, dressing tart, perfect amount of spice, crab perfectly fried.

Tom yum goong - Soup was average.  Very oddly there are two types of shrimp in this soup.  Some large prawns, the others small and not too good looking.  Server serves the soup at the table to the whole party which doesn't happed a lot these days, so a plus for the service...however I was not too thrilled about her fingers touching the inside of the bowls...call me anal.

Chilean Sea Bass - you can choose from three different sauces for them to cook it.  We chose garlic...this was the highlight of the meal.  Very good.

Green curry - I almost don't eat rice these days, but I ate two bowls with the curry sauce, need I say more?  Server also scooped the rice for us....plus again for the service.

Bamboo & Egg - Extremely salty.  Hope this was an accident, if it is the norm, I would not recommend it.
author: Jenny K.

description:
This place is a no brainer.  You like Tai food?  You will love Marnee.  I live around the corner from this place, and I have tried most of the menu, and everything is good, and yes this is a run on sentence, but thats how good this place is!
I really like the Tam ka soup, because its a little spicy (not too much), and lemongrassy (just right).  You just want to pick up the bowl and slurp that shit.
The service is fast and courteous.  The only thing that you have to watch out for is when you get takeout, be sure you got the hot sauce in the bag because they always say they put some in, but half the time its not in there.  Or do what I do: grab a couple of extra sauces from their stash and out the door like a school girl.
author: Crispsy B.

description:
Someone said Marnee Thai isn't thai food?  are you kidding me?  or really am i just totally out of the loop.  for all i know, the food i had was definitely thai.  Anyways, maybe someone can enlighten me on that.

Came here with some friends and I liked it very much.  I think the kitchen area and the window looking into the kitchen makes it look like those chinese restaurant type joints.  but the dining area is pretty cool.  It's not too pricey, and really it depends on what you order.  I tend to try and not order something that I've had elsewhere that's pretty good, unless, which is this case, someone says this one is much better.

But we had the following:
-Red Curry with Duck - really good.  I'm a big fan of curry with coconut milk and i don't think i've had it served with duck meat anywhere else which made this really tasty.  The duck was of course, fatty, but damn, duck meat with the skin and fat with pineapple soaked in coconut curry goodness.....it does wonders.  

- Chiliean Sea Bass with Garlic - good call, Terence.  probably the priciest dish, but definitely well cooked and flavored.  That garlic stayed with me for a while too, but it defintely made the dish that much better.  I also liked the veggies it came with (since none of my friends like vegs even green peas), but the fish was so tender.

-Pad Kaprow (chicken sauteed with thai basils and chli garlic) - was good with rice.  not too spicy either.  

-Spicy Angel Wings - this was what i tought was already good at Osha's but then, try Marnee Thai's who takes it up a notch and puts this sugary garlic and spices sauce which drenches these fried up chicken wings.  you can never go wrong with wings....but with this sauce??  u gotta jus get it whenever u come here.  

I also like how they have a wine list....makes it seem like a classy thai place that way and I definitely got me a small glass of the thai red wine....eh, so so.. i shoulda picked somethin better.

Definitely gonna make a trip back
author: Vincent K.

description:
We came here for a friend's birthday party and had about 12 people there (not too big of a group) - but I think it was too much for this restaurant to handle as they got 2 of our dishes mixed up and our food came out one by one within a span of an hour (meaning people were done as others were JUST getting their food).  I didn't think any of the noodle dishes would take so long, but I guess I was wrong. . .

Most of us orderd pad thai-style dishes (noodle dishes I mean) and we figured all of ours would come out at the same time so we could pass our dishes around and share. . .but it basically felt like we were eating 2 dishes at a time (like having a 5-course meal or something)...and it sucked because sharing 2 plates at a time amongst 12 people really isn't enough food.  We were STARVING and we kept waiting and waiting. . .but no food!  I was especially po-ed because I had ordered 2 dishes to go for someone else and I ordered a dish for myself to eat there. .but they thought my dish was to go as well...wtfreak?!?! Why would I order something for myself to go when I'm there enjoying the dinner party with everyone else?  bogus I tell you - I was not happy with the service at all (and in the beginning, our waiter seemed really cool...deceiving!)  OH, and there's a funk stink to the place too..especially in the very back room we were sitting at. . .

So when I went home to eat my food (my pad see-ew). . .there was a sauce that was placed separately from the noodles and I was confused because I was never given sauce when I ordered it to go. . .I tried it to see if it was something worth dousing my noodles in, and it was SO SALTY AND NASTY!  It also had this funk stink to it and I don't eat things that smell weird. . .but as I ate the noodles it tasted like something was missing. . .therefore I decided what the hecks, I'll pour a little bit over a small chunk of my noodles. .BAD IDEA!  My noodles tasted worse and it was super salty. . .it didn't taste like the dish I used to think was my fav. Thai dish. . .

I will definitely say that Krung Thai (in Santa Clara) is a LOT better than this place. . . in terms of everything: Food, service, cleanliness, odor (which they have no odor of anything funky except for the smell of delicious flavorful food).  I think I'll order me some pad see-ew for lunch today at Krung Thai!!! :P
author: Grace K.

description:
Marnee Thai is a Thai restaurant that cares just a little bit more than your average Thai restaurant. The food is always presented with just a little extra attention than other Thai places. I go here often and I've always had really decent food and service. They are especially good at lunch time. I work close by and only have a limited amount of time at lunch. I'm always in and out and back to work on time.

The Panang Beef is excellent and comes with a side of broccoli, which is good cause we could all use a few more veggies in our diet, right? Since Pad Thai is the standard go to dish for many people, it's a good thing that Marnee's is excellent. The Tom Ka soup is amazing! I can't seem to find an alternative place that has Tom Ka this good.

I imagine that anything you order at Marnee will be pretty good; however, I went there with a friend today and she had the Green Curry with noodles. The dish was pretty good, but because Marnee is all about the presentation, the noodles were served on the side. The dish would have been better if everything had been mixed up while it was being cooked.

Overall, Marnee Thai is a great Thai restaurant in the Inner Sunset.
author: Tash T.

description:
This Marnee Thai looks nothing like the other one. The other Marnee has cute decorated lighting and a hut-like interior with more of a homey feel to it. This restaurant is just a row of tables. There's a counter with individual seats but no one sits there because of the clutter which takes up the whole counter space. I was less than impressed. The waitress had to put a dish on the table next to us because there wasn't enough space on ours. I wonder what would happen if there were people next to us, cuz I sure ain't sharin' my red curry with anybody but me, ya dig?

The food was good, but I think they don't make the dishes as well as the other Marnee. Also, I did not particularly love that the waitress loudy said to my mom as we were leaving, "Are you the mother? You look like you could be sisters!" Lady, I know you're trying to give my mom a compliment and everything (which my mom secretly loves by the way), but some people wouldn't want it to be rubbed in their face like that. Not cool. Or maybe I've just got my panties in a bunch.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I used to come here once a month when I lived on 12th.  This place is great.  I like the quick service and tasty food.

It could be a little salty..but if you like spicy thai food go here now!  Recently made their thai fried race spicy and I'm not even a spicy eater and it tasted like a party in my mouth!  BOOM!  I love it.

Usually there isn't a terrible line here and prices are reasonable.  It's like a hidden gem in the inner sunset!  If you can't go to san tung or want Thai food and you're in the area..go here.
author: Yup S.

description:
Interesting factoids about, or at least loosely related to, Marnee Thai:

* The woman who appears to be the owner also appears to be married to the head chef. Given these facts, it is difficult to discern whether the commands she sometimes shrieks toward the kitchen concern matters of business or matters of love.

* The worst part about eating at Marnee Thai:  When, because of the deliciousness of their Pad Kee Mao, which you always get because you're practically nuts for Thai Basil, and which is considerably less oily than the Pad Kee Mao at your other favorite Thai haunts, you break with your normal habit of giving restaurant leftovers to that homeless guy that's always at the corner of 9th and Irving, instead saving your little bundle of spicy, basil-y noodles for your own breakfast the following day. (I'll hit you next time, buddy.)

* Because I've met the owner of Marnee Thai, and because the owner of Marnee Thai has met Dr. Ruth, there is only one degree of separation between me and Dr. Ruth.
author: Shaun E.

description: I've been here more than a dozen times and have yet to have a poor meal, poor or slow service. Excellent Pad Se Ew. However, it's a very narrow dining area. If I wasn't so nervous about getting bumped as people pass I would be more relaxed and enjoy it more. Still four stars for the best reasonably-priced Thai food I've had in the Bay Area.
author: Jerry D.

description:
This review is long over due, I went here a couple years ago with a girl I was dating at that time, her and her sisters where friends with them, so we got great service (of course) and the food was good and priced well.  We went on a weeknight so there were lots of open tables. 
It's been a couple years since I dated her, so I guess I should try this place again, this time as a regular customer. (without special treatment)
author: C J.

description:
Great thai food here, not too greasy, with good clean preparation.  Lots of interesting curries, including a pumpkin curry, that are ALL tasty.  Chef's got talent.
Try their Banana blossom salad...pretty rare to find, and it kicks ass...tastes like bamboo shoots/artichokes.  TASTY!

Ambience is good, and service is serviceable.  Pretty quiet overall so good to take a date too.

This is my favorite Thai in the city so far... have to try the original Marnee, but with this one so close to where I live, it's hard to get over there.
author: Fong L.

description: This is some of the best thai food I've ever had and I just got back from a month in Thailand.  The wine list is great and very affordable and the specials were delicious. I can not wait to go back here. It is also a nice date spot since the decor is so pretty and the prices are very reasonable for top notch thai cuisine.
author: Cody L.

description:
4.5 stars.

Sawatdee, Marnee Thai! We rolled into your bustling restaurant seeking fiery chilies, Thai basil, lemongrass, and ginger, and departed with ideas for dinner parties, evenings at home, and lazy breakfasts. Your kabocha squash curry with fried tofu, sensational miang kum (stuffed spinach leaves with crushed peanut, chopped ginger, pickled onions, dried shrimp, and toasted coconut), and custard sweet cakes served in cast iron egg wells thrilled our taste buds and excited our imaginations. Then, your comforting noodles and crunchy Chinese broccoli calmed our senses, smoothing our waves of ecstasy so we could bear the crispy sweetness of curled roti served with the richest coconut ice cream of memory. Most of our party also swooned over your pad kaprow with prawns, but I personally like my dishes less salty. Still, your ebullient servers, comfortable seating, and brisk plating provided us with a joyful evening.
author: Brianne C.

description:
This was one of the WORST dining experiences I have ever encountered and I eat out 3-4 times a week.  This was my first time here in this restaurant.

1.  To start, we walked in around 6:30 pm on a weeknight (party of 3),  there wasn't anyone ahead of us in line.  The waitress told us to follow her, 3/4 into the restaurants, she said the table wasn't ready and told us to go back out and wait by the entrance even though there were 2 tables available.    

2.  We waited & finally got seated, but no one was around to take our orders even though I tried to get their attention.  Finally, this woman shows up for work (we saw her walked in the front door and proceeded to the kitchen to put her purse down).

3.  She then came over & started taking our order . . . She was EXTREMELY PUSHY and wanted us to order more food and in particular, order the more expensive dishes.  I have no problem paying more but I can't stand the PUSHINESS.  It was downright obnoxious!

4.  The Drink - I ordered the Thai Sake but they didn't have it, so I settled on a regular hot sake.  They bought it to the wrong table (the one next to us).  The younger wait staff appeared to be totally inexperienced.

5.  The Food - The soup was warm, not hot (in temperature), I don't understand why!  A young waiter brought out a dish which he said was Shrimps & Scallops.  Turns out it was the garlic Sea Bass that we ordered.  It was ok for $16.95.  I expected more.  But seriously, if he didn't know what the dish was, I'd prefer he didn't announce it and just say "Enjoy".  Then came the chicken curry, meat was dry and the taste was mediocre at best.  Once again, it was just warm, not hot.   We finally got the shrimps & scallops dish, it was the best one but still, it wasn't anything that special (although it was supposed to be one of the house specialties).  I've had much better Thai food elsewhere.

6.  After we finished our meal, the waitress came back and wanted to take our dessert order.  When we declined, she seemed to disapprove our decision.  

7.  On a side note, the table across from us got their check while they were waiting for their dessert.  When they asked our same waitress about the dessert, she said "I didn't know you ordered dessert".  Huh?  One of the 4 people said "We have the little dishes and the forks sitting here waiting for our dessert".  Oh, mine, it's like they have to prove it, how rude!  I'm sure they were not pleased!

At this point, I couldn't wait to get out of there when I heard "Come back & see us soon".  Well, I think NOT!  Again, it was a very very BAD dining experience which I hope no one has to go through.

There are plenty of better places out there.  I recommend SKIPPING this one.
author: L T.

description:
First impressions are important...this one? not so great. Place felt small...we were greeted by a hostess, asked what the wait time was and she said 5 mins...10 mins later, someone else walked in and asked for wait time, 5 mins (says the hostess)...20mins, finally seated. 

Back room seating area was cold. Waited to order, waited for food...actually waited for a looooong time for food to arrive. When the food finally came, none came with the rice we had ordered...so we waited, and waited...asked for it, and waited some more, asked for it again before it came. dessert: who eats ice cream with a fork?? thought it was a mistake but when we looked over to the table next to us, they got a fork too..were they out of spoons?

in conclusion: disappointed, rating: 2-3 stars but i'm feeling nice today so 3.
author: meL Z.

description:
This review is for the Marnee Thai in the Outer Sunset by the way:

I used to love going here - both the food and the service had been great. So, you ask why one star? Well, the last time I went, service was absolutely horrible (we didn't get the waiter and waitress we had in the past). First, we had to flag down the waitress to order. When we ordered, she had a "I-could-care-less" type of attitude.  Then, when our orders arrived, she put down all three bowls of soup at the side of the table. She didn't care to find out whose order was whose, and set it down at that person's place. Nope, she just set it down abruptly and walked away. We were left  experimenting each dish, just to find out whose soup was whose. It was ridiculous, especially considering that the bowls of soup were extremely hot to the touch and hard to move. 

That was bad - but what was unacceptable was when the bill arrived. She had overcharged us for one dish. My dad went to tell her that she had overcharged us. She then gave us the cash difference - but my dad reminded her that they owed us not just the cash difference between the price of the dishes, but also the tax difference. She played dumb for a minute, and then said it was not their policy to refund tax. Then, she said very loudly - so that all patrons could hear -- "What? You want two cents back? Fine! I'll give you two cents back!" My dad replied, "It's not the two cents - it's the fact that not only did you overcharge us, but you didn't properly refund us either for a mistake on your part." 

After all this - not one word of apology or an attempt to make up for this awfully poor experience. Instead, she tried to embarrass my dad for asking her to refund us completely for her mistake. We are not going back, no matter how good the food is.
author: Carolyn M.

description:
I love the location of this place - I feel a little spoiled to have it right by my place.  The owner is so nice, and makes the experience very personal.  The food was delicious, I have a chicken noodle dish, can't remember the exact name but it was really good, I had a bit of my friend's dish and it was also good.

After the great meal, we were served dessert and they have the best ice cream.  the nice thing is that also they have large portions, so I was able to enjoy my meal again for lunch and be the envy of my coworkers
author: Silvia T.

description:
After Mekong shut down (sob, but lets not go there), we found Marnee Thai and it became our favorite Thai place. 

Try the tofu angel wings - the sauce is awesome and our meat loving amigos say the tofu works better than the chicken because its a better carrier of the sauce. 

The soy protein is very soft with great texture, try it with any of the dishes. We have loved everything we try there. The spices are done just right. Great  Thai Food!
author: Dharti A.

description:
I don't know what it is, but I seem to crave Marnee Thai when I've been out of the country. There's just something awesome about fresh and flavorful Thai food after traveling places devoid of any great Asian food. 

Anyway...my husband loves the Angel Wings here and we recently enjoyed a eggplant basil dish and vegetables in a peanut sauce. We skipped the mango and sticky rice this last time but greatly enjoy their version.
author: Shannon W.

description: Their thai friend rice is unbelievably good. And the fish sauce... yum. I want some just writing about it! The atmosphere is a bit crowded, so I usually get takeout.
author: Emma S.

description:
Every time we passed by this place, it looked tiny, packed and crampy. We finally decided to try it out (succumbing to the Zagat, Yelp logos at the entrance) on a week night not holding high hopes but to our surprise this restaurant delivered in a big way. 

Dinner started with the coconut cake appetizer (which took a while to come but well-worth the wait) on the special menu. Made with rice floor, coconut, cream, sugar with grated coconut on top: the cake is soft on the inside crisp at the bottom cooked on a cast iron plate somewhat like those used for escargot. Add a dab of the spicy sour chilli sauce on the table and heaven had arrived on our taste buds.

Next up was the bbq chicken. Ordinary looking but extemely well-favored, sweet lightly charred chicken so soft and tender they almost fell off the bones. Yum.

The green curry was slightly less thick than usual but nonetheless tasted fresh with the egg plant delicious in the mix.
  
Service was top-notched. Water topped up relentlessly and hosts friendly. This is very likely the best Thai restaurant in the bay area (at least on that night). For once, Yelp rating makes sense  :).
author: M Y.

description:
This is one of those places I think that thrives solely on its hype.

As a rule, I generally consider good service to make up for bad food, and good food to make up for bad service. 

So when the waitress here seated us with a glance from the register, nodding absentmindedly towards a table and then proceeding to ignore us for an agonizing, stomach-grumbling fifteen minutes, my mouth instantly began watering. Why? 
'With such shitty service and yet such great yelp reviews,' I thought, 'this place must have some BOMB-ass food!!'

I was pretty excited. Another fifteen minutes passed, and our orders arrived. A text-messaged recommendation from an SF local friend prompted us to try the spicy Angel-wings. My sister and I both being in curry-licious moods, ordered the vegetarian red curry and the roasted duck curry.

The angel-wings were tasty. "Nothing to write home about," my sister said. The curries were completely ordinary. "Nothing to warrant a five-star review," I said. I think the decor, the "hole-in-the-wall" feel of the place, combined with the trendy square dishes are what's feeding the madness surrounding this restaurant. Bit of a disappointment.
author: Stef H.

description:
I haven't been to this place since I was a kid. My mom used to say that I used to fiend for the Angel Wings. I'm not sure why we stopped going.

Anyways I hit up the one in 9nth incarnation recently. Wow it has changed. It used to be a really old mom and pop almost a dive type of restaurant. They've updated the furniture and decorations, but not overly so. I hate it when a place redecorates in attempt to look modern and it ends up being a pretentious & garish disaster. That didn't happen here.

Anyways here was the hit list: Chilean Sea Bass, Angel Wings, Vegetarian Pad Thai, and Mango Crab Fried Rice. The dessert was Rotti with Coconut.

The Chilean Sea Bass was awesome! It had a flaky and mildy spiced exterior. Their was a hint of a Chili flavor in their that was nicely paired with the texture of the bass. The interior was succulent and juicy. What a flavorful fish! It was paired with some bok choy. The Chilean Sea Bass is a seasonal item. The waiter informed me that it was only available in the winter months.

The Angel Wings were good. Not as good as I remembered them, but I think that's because my palette has matured. A neat little tasty treat is to pour the sauce of the Angel Wings on to the rice. It's really delicious.

The Pad Thai and the Fried Rice were also great, but the Sea Bass really stole the show.

The Thai Ice tea was great! The tea was the perfect strength for me and the milk was added just right. Also it was lightly iced so the tea didn't taste diluted later.

The Rotti with Coconut Ice cream was a pleasant surprise as well. I learned that Rotti is a kind of fritter mixed with sugar and butter. It had a crispy exterior and a fluffy interior. Like all fried foods it is a great contrast to the ice cream. Our waiter was friendly and extremely helpful!


Great smelling bathrooms as well.
author: Poincare's Conjecture N.

description:
Food: Delicious! I've tried the beef salad, pad sew ew, and roti with ice cream. The beef salad was tasty, I loved the lime dressing and the pad sew ew was made with a thinner rice noodle which was nice. The roti is so sweet but a wonderful way to conclude a meal! Nice portions too.

Price: Not bad at all. Lunch items are under $10 and for dinner the price goes up maybe a $1 or so for entree items. 

Service: Fast and speedy waiters!

Atmosphere: A nice, intimate restaurant. I actually like dining at this location better. A good date spot.

Location: Located on 9th. Parking available at meters or in the park.
author: Miss H K.

description:
Meh.  Marnee was kind of disappointing and not impressive.  I'm not sure what all the great reviews are about, but maybe we ordered the wrong dishes.  We got the imperial rolls appetizer and then shared the mango fried rice with chicken and a vegetarian eggplant and tofu dish.  The mango fried rice is what I was most excited about, but it wasn't all that special and didn't even have much mango in it.  The eggplant dish was too salty and the imperial rolls were kind of boring.

The good things - the service was quick, the food is affordable, and the Thai iced tea was delicious!

That said, I don't think I'll be back - there are much better options for Thai around the city.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Mom and I had a dinner date at Marnee on a Tuesday evening and made sure to get there earlyish (5:30) to avoid the horrid lines everyone keeps talking about.  

Let's get one thing straight.  Mom is old school Chinese, which means she is frugal as hell...frugal like wear your clothes til they have holes in them, and when they can't be worn anymore, use them as rags, and when they can't be used as rags anymore, cut them into strips to tie things up with, and when they can't tie up anymore then...um ok I went a little too far haha.  Point being..if Mom says her meal was "veh-lee good" and worth the money, then Marnee is very good indeed.

The Hot Cakes listed on their 'Specials' menu are a must.  They take an extra 10-15 minutes but are totally worth the wait.  Perfectly crisp on the outside and ooey gooey on the inside, they are burn-the-roof-of-your-mouth HOT but oh so delicious.  

Pad Pra Ram was just as tasty: sauteed sliced chicken in peanut curry with coconut milk served on spinach.  This dish is the perfect accompaniment to a serving of rice.  It's also one of the few dishes that isn't marked as "spicy" which was great for Mom who can't handle spiciness. 

Pad Thai is a must order wherever I go.  Marnee's version is good on flavor but is a bit dry.  

One star off for end-of-the-meal weirdness. I ordered dessert and asked some boxes.  Lady #1 takes our plates to box up, but forgets our rice so I ask Lady #2 to please box it up as well.  Lady #3 asks if we want to order dessert.  Um, we already did.  Lady #3 returns with just the tiny box of rice.  Er, we have 2 other entrees?  Lady #3 returns to the kitchen and comes out empty handed, runs over to Lady #1 and #2 with confused look on her face.  Lady #1 and 2 look at each other.  Mom and I look at each other like..what the fuck happened? Did they throw away our dishes?  Lady #1 asks what we ordered and Lady #2 asks if we want to order dessert [AGAIN!!]. In my head: Are you gonna cook us our dishes again or what?  I want my leftovers!!  All of a sudden, a bag emerges from the back.  Where the hell was it this entire time?  I double check to make sure it's actually our food.  It is.  *whew!*  Well that was weird. 

Thankfully the mango sticky rice was delicious and the presentation was quite lovely.  Other than the near fiasco, Marnee Thai did not disappoint.  Mom happy = me happy.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I had lunch here with a friend and I literally couldn't decide what to order off the lunch menu cause everything sounded so good!.  

Decided on the red curry, tofu and rice noodles dish.  When it came,the rice noodles were on the side, so I could add as many noodles as I wanted to the curry.  This is a plus in my book as I wasn't feeling the need to carb-load myself.  


If you order from the dinner menu, they can substitute veg soy protein in any of the chicken/beef/pork  wok based dishes off the dinner menu. That alone would bring me back for another meal here.
author: Smruti S.

description:
This place is awesome!

The vegetarian green curry was perfectly spicy and full of many different veggies. The reason I gave it 4 stars and not 5 is because of the tofu. The tofu in the dish was mushy and overfried. The pad see yu noodles were cooked perfectly. The portions are generous and full of awesome spices!
author: Ben B.

description:
Which way do you swing: Marnee Thai 1 (on Irving) or Marnee Thai 2 (on 9th)? Jack or Sawyer? McDreamy, McSteamy or George? All extremely complex questions... 

Marnee Thai 2 on 9th Street is closer to my place, but like Sawyer, Marnee Thai 1 has more internal spunk and dining room character.  

They are both lightning fast from food order to table arrival, but getting take out from the 9th street branch seems a few minutes faster. 

The finger licking tastiness scale is equally high at both places, so when it comes down to it, the question is: what kind of person are you? And how far are you willing to travel for an unsolicited face reading (only available at Marnee Thai 1)?

For the record - I'd pick Marnee Thai 1, Sawyer, and George every time.
author: Shan M.

description: As a restaurant overall, this place gets three stars.  I like Chabaa better.  But four stars for their mango sticky rice, it is one of the best in the city.
author: Erika C.

description: If I'm going to eat Thai in the City, Marnee wouldn't be my first choice.  I've been to both spots now, the outer sunset and inner sunset locations, and although the food is not bad at all, I prefer some of the other many options in SF. Both locations can get crowded as they are quite popular spots. Their curries are pretty good and the popular angel chicken wings are tasty and will stay piping hot (temperature-wise) during your entire meal, but I just feel you might be able to get better Thai entrees elsewhere.
author: Erich D.

description: Had spring rolls that were ok, ordered curry panang Thai hot. I got a panang that was mild. My friend who likes his food bland got exactly what he ordered. The side of peanut sauce I paid for, tasted as though it only had one peanut in it. Very disappointing. The service was pretty first rate. We had a host, waiter, server and busboy and some random person. Our water glasses were never less than 1/2 full and never wanted for anything other than tastier food.
author: Leon F.

description:
Marnee Thai is my go-to thai place in SF.  The food is scrumptious.  Last night was no exception.  A friend and I split :

1. Miang Kum appetizer-* highly recommended*
(spinach wrapped with dried shrimps, onions, lime wedges, ginger, toasted fresh coconut and peanuts, served with a delicioso dipping sauce)

2.  Vegetarian Curry in Red Sauce
3.  Pad Thai with prawns
4.  Dessert-  Black Rice with coconut ice cream


Outstanding!
author: Krista C.

description:
We've been slowly going through restaurant recommendations given to us by various friends native to SF and Marnee Thai came up quite a few times. We came in on an early Saturday night around 6pm and the place was somewhat empty. The space was quite small (narrow and long), but the overall ambiance was nice except that there was a loud refrigerator type noise constantly go on and off. 

We ordered the Golden Triangles Thai Samosas, Soft shell crab with green papaya salad, and basa fillet. Let me tell you, the samosas were the best I've ever had. EVAR! They were pipin' hot, crunch on the outside, and amazingly flavorful on the inside. The soft shell crab on green papaya salad was quite good too. The crab was fried, very crunchy and seasoned nicely. It was definitely the way to make a healthy papaya salad instantly become unhealthy with fried goodness. The basa fillet was nothing to rave about and I'd likely try something else next time. I like the flavor of peppercorn, but am not too much of a fan of whole peppercorns in the dish, so I ended up picking them all out. 

Service was very responsive here. Water was always filled and it was easy to get the attention of the waiters. During the time we went, the cooks/employees were also having their meal, and boy did I want to know what they were eating too! They're food looked really carb heavy, but I swear they had these really good looking things that looked like chicken nuggets. I'd love to come back here again and check out their other dishes.
author: Gloria C.

description:
I was worried about visiting this location because the other one is so perfect.... but after two visits I am amazed and pleased at how consistent these two places are.  Excellent thai food.  The owner was at this one this time for lunch - yay!  It's always nice to see her.  She is full of life and a great hostess.

The pad kee mao is my favorite - extra spicy.  And the young coconut juice.  And DO try the homemade roti sometime.... it is to die for!  Literally if you eat it too often and don't exercise.

Great lunch spot (and dinner I'm sure) and late hours too.  Perfect for after a nice day in the park.  Go with your loved one.  Or by yourself and read a book!

XOXO I love Marnee Thai!
author: Aaron W.

description:
I had a dream last night that I was writing a yelp review and felt remorseful at having to write a poor review for a restaurant I really wanted to like.  Now I'm questioning if I actually wrote the review.  Do your dreams ever mix with your reality?  I don't know if I feel this dream is bordering on a pathetic obsession or if its somewhat comical, perhaps an even distribution of the two.  But, since I can't remember what I wrote or didn't, I thought I would share my latest experience at Marnee Thai.  

It was great.  Food, service, attire of the staff, price, attention to detail, all great.  I will definitely be back.  

BTW -  I had the pumpkin curry (red) and it was excellent.  Highly recommend it.  Also, they have brown rice now.
author: Rachel C.

description:
This is a nice restaurant to go to when you want someplace with a bit more ambiance than your usual hole-in-the-wall Thai eatery.  Marnee is great for groups (so long as you call ahead) and has an extensive menu that is both carnivore and vegetarian-friendly.  (They are very accommodating towards vegetarians, as most dishes can be made sans-meat.) 

Their Thai samosas are amazing--crisp, yet not excessively greasy, as I find most samosas.  The avocado/mango salad was tasty (but how can you go wrong with those two?) and the perfect level of spiciness, just a tad heavy on the dressing. The spring rolls weren't anything special, but I was pleased they could substitute the shrimp in them with tofu.
author: A. T.

description: Good food at a good price. Only thing keeping this from four stars is the restaurant. Maybe it was just my timing but there was a weird pressure wha-wha going on the whole time. Like someone had a window down on the highway. I'd get my food to-go next time unless it's fixed.
author: Tori J.

description: Marnee Thai still has the best Thai food I have had in the city. The food is consistently delicious, and the staff always treats us well. You can't beat their Pad Thai. The Angel Wings and Chicken Larb Salad are must haves as well. Marnee Thai will certainly continue to be one of my favorite dining establishments.
author: Zac T.

description: I love this place and I think it my favorite Thai restaurant ever. Do not miss the basa (Vietnamese catfish) with equal parts garlic and fish. I also love, love, love the curry with pumpkin (specifically kabocha). Other dishes have been very good - papaya salad, yellow curry, soups, etc. This restaurant as opposed to the one in the Outer Sunset is less crowded and more relaxed.
author: Marco M.

description:
I've been here twice and both times were somehow related to a bad date. The first time was after a truly awful (and rainy) date, while the second was part of a date that, while not truly bad, was lacking in chemistry and generally blah.

Unfortunately, that's how I feel about Marnee Thai: lacking in chemistry and rather blah. I've heard and read so many good things about this restaurant that I find myself wanting to like this place more than I actually do. My food was just OK, so I'd rather try some of the other dozens of Thai joints in this town before coming back here.
author: Katie I.

description:
No matter how many times I come back to Marnee, either on Irving or here on 9th Street, I always come away impressed.

Having just come back from Southeast Asia (Vietnam and Cambodia) and having been wowed by the food over there, a trip to Marnee is like a trip back to Vietnam.  The food is fresh and flavorful, perfectly spiced and generous.

Last night we had an extraordinary Mango salad that puts your average Green Papaya salad to shame and we took advantage of it still being crab season to get an absolutely amazing crab noodle dish (#47!).  The owner came by to tell us that Gourmet magazine had just requested the recipe for that dish...and we understand why.  Wow.

Wrapping up the main meal, we had a lovely Green Curry with thin an tender pork - and just enough sliced chilis to keep you on your toes.

Of course, no trip to a Thai restaurant would be complete without a dash of Mango with Sticky Rice...and Marnee does not disappoint.  Their black sticky rice is sticky, but not overly-clumpy, lightly sweetened, and served with perfectly-ripe, thin-sliced mango.  Perfection!
author: Josh M.

description: YUMO!!!! Wow, this place is mouth watering Thai goodness. The green curry is amazing and they have a coconut soup that is so unbelievably good I want to just bathe in it. If you haven't had their Mango Fried Rice it is also an absolute MUST have! Trust me when I say.. don't waste time on the appetizers because the main dishes are just too darn good. The prices are great so even if you order too much food you can always take it home and still not break the bank which is always something to think about. I recommend making a reservation just because it means that your wait time might be 5 minutes or less and trust me, once you walk in and start smelling all of those delicious smells, your mouth will start salivating and you won't be able to wait to dive into your soon to be food coma of happiness.
author: Kylie L.

description:
My friend has been talking about this place for awhile, and i finally tried it tonight...and it's just as good as he said it would be.  it's a tiny place, so the quarters are a little cramped, but i guess it's part of the charm.  we got the chicken satay appetizer...one of my favorite appetizers in general.  we had the mango fried rice with chicken, and the garlic pepper sea bass...i am not a big fan of seafood, but this dish was the bomb., as was the mango fried rice.  We also picked up some Pad See-Yu to go (not for us, for a friend - we were ready to burst after our own meal)...but we sampled it (naturally) and it was excellent as well.

The portions are good sized and there was enough to be boxed up and taken home for a late night snack or lunch for tomorrow.  It's not super-cheap...the fried rice was $9 bucks, and the sea bass was $16, but not outrageous.  And well worth it.  I'd recommend it to anyone, and I will definitely be going back soon.

The portions are
author: Spookee X.

description:
There was a time in my life when I didn't go a week without a Marnee fix. Those days are perhaps long gone. 

This is my favorite place in the sunset for Thai food. The service is also really great.
author: Stacy F.

description:
No fishless curry! Booo! 

Pad Si Eu (am I spelling that right?), and fried rice and spring rolls were all standard. 

The weird little back area where we were seated had no cell recetion, which of course, shouldn't matter in a resto, except that we were trying to meet someone, and that made it difficult. 

Overall, another mediocre SF Thai experience.
author: Jeani H.

description:
Tried it one more time recently and found the experience to be ridiculous.  The food was better, but definitely not what I would consider to be the best Thai in the City.  

I went with 2 other people.  We ordered grouper with pepper & garlic, soup (one cup each), green curry, and one young coconut juice.  

Soup--was very tasty, no complaints there

Grouper--what an unbelievable rip off!  The size of the piece of fish was about 3 in x 3 in.  There was more bok choy on the plate than fish.  It tasted great, but honestly that dish wouldn't even feed one person.  this was $17.

Green curry--tasted like every other green curry I have ever eaten.  With the chicken sliced so thin and everything, it wasn't much food at all.

They charged $4.50 for steamed white rice!  Unbelievable!  There wasn't even enough rice in the bowl to fill us up.

So for $65, we got mediocre food and left hungry.  I'm NEVER going back there.  They are not nearly good enough to be charging more than other Thai restaurants for less food, it's absurd.
author: Kandi K.

description: Good food, terrible service. Waited an hour for a table, another 1/2 hour or more for food. They brought out dishes for each member of our party (7) one at a time with long stretches in between. This was the middle of the day on a weekday.
author: Vince L.

description: Second time here. Food and service are great but no other review seems to mention the really unsettling low frequency humming sound that makes having a conversation near impossible. I really want to like this place but that is the single one thing that kills it for me.
author: Dr K.

description: The owner is real pushy.  If you don't like someone trying to push you every dish and overselling you food, then this is not a place for you.  She kept on saying it's not enough food but we order way too much (half of which had to be boxed to go).  She also tries to push you things that are not popular so she can get rid of them.  We ordered a soup and she asked how many people were having it.  I said we just want whatever the normal size is as listed on the menu.  However, she insisted on the number of people so we said 4.  She later charged us 50% more because the soup was meant for 2 people.
author: Lily Y.

description: Based on all of the positive reviews, I thought that I would like this restaurant but sadly it was a disappointment.  I order pad kee mao, tom yum shrimp soup, seafood chili stir fry and angel wings.  The portions are smaller than average.  Quality wise, the food was really oily and was not spicy at all, flavor is sort of bland. Americanized Thai food that is comparable to food court.  The best thing I had was the homemade chili sauce which I believe was a blend of garlic and chili, however, it wasn't enough to save the dishes.
author: Eva E.

description:
I went here on a date recently..and must say that I was pleasantly surprised at how vast the menu was and the affordable prices.  We were seated in the waiting area for a few minutes but were handed menus to peruse while we waited, after a short wait, we were seated.  While we sat, our water was filled, and more time was given for us to browse through the menu.  We started by ordering the Angel Wings..basically chicken wings fried and then basted with this honey, barbeque gingery sauce..a lot of sauce.  Once you get thru all the sauce, you get down to some tender yummy chicken.  I cleaned them down to the bones. =) yum.  Next came our chicken satay dish (?) i think, and the pad see maw. We asked for everything to be extra spicy...

The chicken satay dish was good, the chicken was tender, tasty and there were slices of green pepper in it.  Good, nothing to write home about...and definitely not spicy.  So we dipped into the pad see maw...IS there ANY spices in this dish at all?? Yes, it was tasty, saucy and a generous portion..but we asked for EXTRA spicy..and i hardly got a kick. 

All in all...my date was the best part of the dinner ;)
author: Lulu C.

description:
Great Thai food!  I recently came here with a few friends for dinner.  Made a reservation a few days before, and we were immediately seated upon walking in.  One of our friends who has been here several times and is from Thailand did all the ordering for our table.  Everything was so good!  The only complaint would be the time it took for us to get our food.  Seemed like there were a few tables around us all getting their meals and we were still waiting on our appetizers.  Also, we were seated in the back of the restaurant very close to the bathroom...not so pleasant :( 

The food itself was REALLY good and well worth a trip back!
author: Julie M.

description:
Overrated, but decent. They have a large party room hidden in the back. If you want something spicy, you have to REALLY ask for it. Preferably in Thai. I asked for *extra* spicy pad kee mao, which turned out to be rather unspicy (but tasty). Portions are medium-sized and fairly priced.

Ploy II is probably my current favorite Thai place in SF, although I haven't really tried many others since I moved here.
author: Tony G.

description: Wow!  I went here with a few SF natives last night.  They really know how to pick good places to eat.  We had a party of eight and we probably waited no longer than 15 or 20 minutes max on a busy Friday night.  Talk about accommodating.  Most places wait until your entire party is present before even seating a party that large.  I ordered the spicy tofu which was just perfect.  You could specify the hotness so I went for a medium hot which had just enough savory spiciness without overwhelming the system.  We shared some appetizers and desserts all of which made my mouth and stomach satisfied.  The prices weren't terribly expensive either.  I think our bill was about $150 including drinks and dessert.  Not a bad deal for a party of eight.  It's walking distance from Golden Gate Park.
author: Amy J.

description:
I'm here mulling over the fairness in submitting a review for a place from which I have yet to have sampled a morsel of food; and usually I would admit that it is not. (note the use of usually) But extraordinary circumstances call for extraordinary measures I say. Here's why...

I saw a favorable review on "Check please--Bay Area" and made a reservation a day in advance for my mother's birthday. Knowing the popularity of the place I asked the host if this was feasible and whether we had any chance of getting in. He assured me it was, so I decided it was worth the risk.

 We show up 20 min before the res. time just to check in, but find a crushing, bewildering morass of customers with, and without reservations, some still waiting for tables 1 hour after their previously scheduled res. time, yet other "walk-ups" with large parties seem to be getting in at a fraction of a wait than those waiting for hours. All this compounded by an overly passive, avoidant waitstaff who seem to be  inwardly praying, "if we just ignore them, maybe they'll all go away." 

Time passes, our res. time comes and goes. I kindly ask the "host" every 15 mins. where we are on the list, he checks my name and so utters the soon oft repeated refrain, "give me five more minutes."  Another half hour passes. In walks the local celebrity reviewer, dripping false modesty, featured on said show, unannounced with 2 more guests than our party. He of course is seated ahead of us. (To be fair, if I was the owner and in walked the man responsible for 10's of thousands of $'s of new business, I would make special allowances too) Another 15 minutes later, I ask where we are on list, "5 more minutes please." So, the host remains content to both deny us the chance of having a meal there while simultaneously frittering away the time we could be spending at another restaurant. After waiting an hour past the scheduled res. time, we gave up, settling for a passable Indian place down the street. 

Look Marnee Thai, I applaud your success and understand how longer waits ensue. But don't give false assurances that everything will be fine, reservations will be honored and customers will be fairly helped in due time, due order; because YOU WON'T! You simply won't. Make it a first come first served establishment, or find a way to honor your reservations rather than bypassing them out of neglect, incompetence or sheer favoritism to local "celebrity."
author: Barney F.

description: Best Thai food me and my boyfriend has ever had! I was trying to find a good thai place to go to for my bday and came across this place on yelp, I have to say I did well because everything was on point. The food was amazing, we had the spicy angel wings to start off and then the pumpkin curry w/ rice, pad thai, and for dessert we had the fried banana with coconut icecream mmmm. The service was excellent. One thing I do have to say is when I told my server that this was the best thai I'd ever had she just looked and smiled and shook her head like "yeah I know" hehe kinda like shes heard that before! Definitely plan on coming here next time I'm in town.
author: Natasha A.

description: I've only had Thai food one other time but wasn't really a fan & gave up on it. When leaving Golden Gate Park (STARVING and not wanting to drive back to the bay) we asked someone what was good around the area & 1st words was Marnee Thai. I'm glad I didn't give up completely because service was great & food was just as awesome! It officially opened me back up to Thai food!
author: Marlene L.

description:
I've been a magnet for colds recently. Sometimes, you just need some spicy Thai food when you're all stuffed up, especially since they put the decongestants behind the pharmacy counter.

This location of Marnee Thai is on a crowded block in the Inner Sunset, so good luck with parking. I was surprised that I was able to park my car on Irving to pick up my takeout order. The dining room was nice - a long, narrow section of tables opposite the kitchen and what looked like a bar.

The food was OK. I didn't need fried prawns wrapped in egg roll paper, but they were tasty. The beef curry didn't look fantastic. It looked more like oil than red curry, and the beef wasn't that tender. I preferred the chicken dish.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Solid effing YUM rating.  I love thai food, so does my boyfriend so I think it's safe to say we eat it WAYYY too much.  After a solid afternoon in Golden Gate Park (have you SEEN the butterfly exhibit at the conservatory of flowers....Off the CHAIN) we found oureselves starving and in the Inner Sunset.  Having no clue where to eat we found ourselves at Marnee Thai on the recommendation of the woman working at the boutique across the street. 

The place was a little jammed and there was only one server for a LOT of people, but we did eventually get food and did not have to go anywhere so nothing lost there.  I would note that you will not be here for a quick meal. 

We got the "summer rolls" without the shrimp and they were fresh and crisp.  These were excellent, I hate it when the wrapper is gummy or gross.  For our entrees we got the Ginger Beef which was *good* but not amazing, BF thought the beef quality was a little off I thought it was fine.  The Pad Se Ew with chicken was EXCELLLENT, yes, sooo freaking good, the best i have had so far in this fine town of ours!!  

Seriously, the Pad Se Ew may actually result in us taking the N Judah across town to eat here, it was that good!  

Great stop off after cruising the park on the weekend and getting your appetite up!
author: Claire C.

description: I don't care how great the food is - my experience here was awful!  We had reservations and they purposely overbook so we had to wait 1/2 hour!  We were in the back room, it was stuffy, we waited so long tp be served.  Lots of apologies, but it didn't make the experience better.  After about $90 of food which was o.k. I felt bad that we came to celebrate a birthday.  We all couldn't wait to get outta there!!!  Even the people who did take out had to wait at least 20 minutes for their order.  I decided that it's not Marnee Thai, it's Marnee Bah -bye!
author: Luri S.

description:
Food's alright, nothing spectacular. 

Some thing REALLY REALLY irked me today at Marnee Thai.

I went with a friend for dinner and together we ordered 2 dishes.  I said I didn't want rice (I wasn't very hungry and I'm also trying to eat less starchy carbs), and my friend said please just bring him one bowl.  I figured that this way, when the rice comes, I can have a spoonful to satisfy any rice yearnings and he can just finish the bowl. No wasting food, no wasting money, just the right attitude for this economy!

And what happened was that they PURPOSELY brought over the bucket of rice and left it at the table, checkmate, ha!  Now if I eat out of that bucket I have to pay, whereas if they had just brought one rice bowl, LIKE WE HAD REQUESTED, we would've had just the right amount of rice and not have to pay for rice we won't even eat.  

I know what you're thinking... but they leave the big buckets of rice for everyone!   You're just paranoid!

NOoooo!  That bucket of rice was left at our table and the wait person left, whereas for everyone at all the tables around us, the rice was served and plated for the customers, and the bucket then taken away.  

That was just lame.  They dicked us over $1.50 of rice, which isn't a lot, but I don't think I'm going to go back.
author: judy w.

description: Did you know that Marnee Thai also provides free entertainment? My brother from another mother and I were dining here recently and the owner seats herself next to us and starts to give us free readings and free ego boosts! Consistently great food, free compliments and a few laughs I am not against!
author: Natalie S.

description:
came here to meet a group of  friends. michelin star?! i had to join... 

Had the chicken laab - yum! refreshing. reminds me of eating thai food in LA. yummers. 

Yellow curry tofu with potato (or you can get tofu with veggies)... yummy! 

Had the pork special, had egg and bamboo in it too. this was alright.

If i'm in the inner sunset, and friends were craving thai, i'd probably come back. but can't say i'd throw it into my usual mix of "must have" thai places...
author: Judy N.

description:
I speak as a customer, if Thai food is your favorite so mark this restaurant as your top list.  Try some of these items;

1. Fresh Corn Cake
2. Avocado Salad with crab
3. Thai Samosa  
4. Basa Fillet with fresh garlic and black paper sauce
5. Chan Pad Poo (Noodles with crab meat)
6. Pumpkin Curry
7. Pad Cha Talay .(Sauteed combination seafood with fresh herbal sauce and Thai basil)
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
i love marnee thai! their angel chicken wings are so good. The sweet and spicy sauce adds a great Thai flavor, topped with dried basil. Some of my other favorites are the corn cakes, chicken satay wraps, Pad Thai, and Pad See Ew. I like marnee because they have a lot of appetizers and special dishes that you can order. 

In terms of the restaurant environment, it's pretty big because they have a back room that can seat a lot of people. I came here for a friend's birthday party once and there were about 20 people. The service is good too and the prices are reasonable. I would come here over King of Thai. haha.
author: Jessica W.

description: Just got back from a tasty  Xmas eve feast at Marnee Thai.  We popped in at random as it's across the street from my friend's place and were very happy indeed:  The place was packed but we were seated within seconds by a very friendly hostess.  We started with the angel wings, which were splendid; a riot of gooey, sweet and savoury crunch.  A tangy, fresh salad of shredded mango, prawns, cashews, and creamy avocado was next up.  We finished with the ginger chicken:  Very delicate and well proportioned flavours.  The servers were rushed but friendly and were always on hand to re-fill our hot tea.  Marnee Thai was just the thing to put in my xmas stocking.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Love the golden triangle (Thai Samosa) It's a great appetizer for group of 4. Spicy ground pork and Green Curry are also on the must-have list. Go get a Thai Ice Tea, in case you can't stand for the spicy dishes. 

Quick service and great food. It's really difficult to go wrong with Thai food.
author: Chiqui H.

description: One of the best Thai restaurants I've been to for awhile, besides Ocha in Los Angeles. We had the Kang Keaw (green curry), Spicy Angel Wings (their signature appetizer dish - a must get!), Pad Kaprow, Chan Pad Poo (Like Pad Thai but spicer and with crab meat), Thai Iced Tea (must get!!!), and a Chiliean Sea Bass with Garlic (very light, moist, and tasty). The food was not overpowering with any of the spices and everything came out pretty quick.
author: Stanley C.

description:
This place is great!

The decor is very sweet, cute and it is very clean.  It's very small.  We got there early which is good because when we left the place was packed.  And I understand why.

The service was good, very prompt with refilling water and seeing if we needed anything.  It took a while to get the check, but since service was good minus that, I'll overlook it.

The food was fabulous.  The Thai Iced Tea was yummy!  We started off sharing a Green Papaya salad, which had a real kick too it.  Great, but for those of you who don't like spicy food be warned!  I had Pad Prew  Wharn - chicken, pineapple, bell peppers and onions in a sweet and sour sauce.  Wow, some of the best food I've had yet since I moved here (two weeks ago, but still!).  I'm absolutely going to be a repeat customer.
author: Jen K.

description:
Loved it!!

Service was attentive and friendly -- servers seemed happy to be working here.

I went out with 4 folks & had one of the best meals I've ever had.  We shared 3 appetizers and 3 main dishes.  We generally just tried the specials and were really happy.  And the black sticky rice with mango -- amaaaazing!  

The appetizers -- you have to try the hotcakes.  So unique and delicious.  Also the avacado & shrimp salad.  And the chicken satay with extras -- the sauce was amazing & wrapping it in butter lettuce with dried coconut made it frickin ridiculous

The main dishes -- We had crab meat & egg noodles -- we couldn't stop eating them.  The snapper curry mousse was good & unique, but not a very strong flavor.  And we tried a soup (the only one w/out coconut milk) which had amazing flavor.

Overall, AMAZING flavors, AMAZING service.  Go out with ~4 folks as you'll find a table & have enough people to share with.
author: A L.

description:
So I was told that Marnee is rivaling Thep Phenom here on Yelp so I had to try it. I must say I'm pretty disappointed. The food was good had I not had any expectations but it's so so bland!  There's no way you can compare this to Thep Phenom's amazing flavors!  The yellow curry was bland and the eggplant dish, which traditionally should have strong flavors were both lacking flavor. I kept pouring that spicy/sour sauce they provide on it to give my taste buds some excitement. On top of this, considering the food was just ok...the prices were a bit high.  Don't know if I'll ever come here again since there are so many better places in the city.

I do have to give their Pad Thai props though!
author: Tanger T.

description:
My fave Thai in the City. Made me fall in love with Pad See-ew (omg my mouth is starting to water just thinking about it...). My usual is a chicken Pad see-ew and a chicken yellow curry. I love yellow curry bc its mild and has huge chunks of potatoes. I recently had the #51 (I think??) its an eggplant dish and it was uber tastey -- and i HATE eggplant. So that's saying something. 

It's nice bc its a quick sit down place in the area and its open all day (no lunch hours and then dinner hours), very reasonably priced, and yums. A caution...I wouldn't order the Thai Iced Coffee...it just doesn't taste very good. The Thai Iced Tea is yummy but sweet as ever so if you don't like sweet drinks, go w/ another option.
author: Grace G.

description:
This is my favorite Thai spot so far.  

That said, since I've put myself on a "boring" diet, I was a bit worried that I'd be in trouble going here for a birthday dinner.  Either I'd eat nothing but lettuce cups, or I'd cave in and feel like crap afterwards.

I managed to find one item in the entire menu that looked like something I could eat in fair moderation - Woonsen Vegetarian (#56).  It's a simple noodle dish with veggies and tofu.  

The noodle is very skinny, clear and tends to stick to each other, which isn't a bad thing in any case.  The veggies aren't fried or otherwise made into something regretful.  The salt content was non-existent, which was a happy surprise.  Overall, it's light and has a fresh taste.

If I'm still on this diet when I come back here, that will be my order again.
author: Don B.

description:
Yum!  Ate here last week and it was very good.  We ordered the corn fritters, which were amazing, a chicken dish, which was super good.  The chicken just fell off the bone!  It was so JUICEY!!!  And we also split the avacado, shrimp, papaya(or was it mango?) salad.

Everything was great!  Brought a bottle of wine and the corkage was only $8.00!  The server was very nice and patient.

I will definetly eat there again!
author: Cyndy P.

description:
There was a good amount of hype going to check out Marnee Thai, two of my foodie friends both rave about it and of course I did a bit of research on my favorite review site YELP before going. 

We went this last Sunday evening and were seated right away, the tables are a bit rammed together so don't try to talk about personal things because I could hear what the people on both sides had to say. We were seated right by the kitchen and it was a constant noise factory of pots and pans being slammed. The service was average, not on it but nothing to really complain about.

They boast that they are original Thai food, and while it was pretty good I do not think that is truly the case. The person I ate with pointed out that the Chicken Larb salad she ordered had lettuce in it instead of cabbage, it was pretty good regardless. I had the green curry with chicken which was good, not the best I have had though, it had a bit of a kick which is what I was looking for. 

I will come back and try some other dishes, however if I am looking for the best Thai food I am probably going to hit Lingba Lounge or Osha Thai for an all together better experience when you include atmosphere, seating and service.
author: Bobby B.

description: Hungry stop on by to Marnee Thai. Really good food Spicy Angel Wings , lip smackin good!
author: Isabella D.

description:
I decided to go to Marnee Thai on a Saturday night around 8:00. It turns out that there is an actual line! I've only been here once before and it was pretty good, but I didn't know that there would be a line. I came with one other person and the wait was estimated at 30 minutes. I actually didn't want to stay because at 8:00pm, you're pretty damn hungry already but I did and we walked through the park for about twenty minutes to kill time.
Turns out that when we got back there were tons of people squished into the tiny restaurant trying to get their names on the list. I was AMAZED and I was thinking... this food better be damn good if its 8:20 and tons of people are trying to eat here. So we eventually got seated in a corner next to a massive plant.
